page.title: 18HOUSING-Brampton
page.content: The lay-out of the original town of Brampton consisted of two streets, a front street and a back street with the end of the front street widening into a market place. It was a collection of tiny overcrowded lanes and yards with cottages built of local red sandstone. Since then, partly due to the sloping ground, the town has developed in detached groups, leaving much open ground close to the centre. The first effort to provide good housing was in the 1930's by the Brampton Public Utility Society when the local council was not making use of the government grants. The society still holds extensive properties today which include small attractive estates mainly of brick-built semi-detached houses with gardens.
